11/ Issues

Real token holder control
Allocation of treasury funds in real time
Fork and create new treasury. Hard not impossible.
Converting treasury to USD is an option, but adds token level sell pressure
Probably 100 more things

/Fin

1116449693599436806.text:
10/ New Value Accrual Model

 $ZRX’s treasury proposal appears to be denominated in ETH. This could usher in a new way to value projects (I.e. how much of a base asset they are accruing times some multiple).
 Only works of the protocol is actually successful (TBD)

1116449692802527246.text:
9/ Example

 $DCR is the easiest example I point to. 10% of block rewards go to a treasury, anyone can submit a proposal, anyone can vote. Just buy a ticket. Simple.

1116449691900706816.text:
8/ Funding is vital

Projects need a model for decades long funding that is central to the protocol itself.

 Funding = path for long term evolution and upgrades by a global base of non-altruistic parties. One-off changes are NOT enough.

1116449691212886024.text:
7/ Treasury aligns stakeholders

Those who own/build on the platform have an incentive to increase the value of the treasury and tokens, since they would be paid in them.

 Brings on non-altruistic builders who can also pay their bills.

1116449690566963226.text:
6/ Instead

Submit a proposal to a treasury, and get paid in tokens. This removes the need to have to earn income on a project or service that is created.

No need to productize = less friction + potentially better apps.

1116449689228980225.text:
4/ On-going protocol level funding removes the need to productize upgrades

For example, in $DCR, a developer can propose an upgrade and get paid in DCR. Same with $XTZ. 

This removes the need to productize services, which could add friction to the use case and development

1116449688557891593.text:
3/ Treasuries = fork resistance

If you fork away, you lose the monetary value of the treasury

Treasury enables an outside party to propose changes that can be funded by the treasury, instead of their own pockets via a fork (only open to rich). Drives greater network effects

1101284545519849473.text:
17)

- For cross linking need 256 validators per shard 

- 8.4m ETH looked up

- 2.8% rewards

1101284318377402368.text:
16) fin

- 32 ETH to validate 
- 1024 shards
- 111 validators per committee 
- 113,664 validators at start 
- 3,637,246 ETH locked up to start 
- max annual validator rewards 4.2%
- this is to start

1101283960573911040.text:
15) phase 3 light clients 

- beyond 2021

- very much still in research 

- 10 posts on stateless clients several years away. 

- minimize on chain data

1101283614761910272.text:
14) phase 2

- repacle evm with eWASM 

- asynchronous cross shard transactions 

- contract yanking (migrating shards)

- ETH 2.0 becomes useful to average software developers 

- development will start this or next year. In research phase. Can happen in parallel with others

1101283171155484672.text:
13) phase 1 shard chains 

- research mostly complete 

- introduces independent shard chains 

- linked at least once per epoch 

- can’t run complex smart contracts between them yet. Used for data storage. Layer 2 can leverage free storage at this time

1101282917765079040.text:
12) beacon chain parameters 

- 6 second blcok times 
- epoch is 64 slots (6.4 minutes) 
- epochs are considered final after 2 epochs

1101282631549898752.text:
11) validators 

- propose blocks and create attestations

1101282370370584581.text:
10) phase 0 become a validator 

- generate an ETH 2.0 address
- generate withdrawal address (cold wallet)
- send 32 ETH and deposit 
- after 1024 blocks deposit considered for voting 
-after 16 epochs validators are voting on the deposit 
- activation queue is FIFO w max churn

1101281905280991232.text:
9) beacon chain 

- 32 ETH to validate 

- shuffling and randomness so there’s no collusion. Shared security pool 

- finalization from PoS - Casper FFG. Finalize blocks in time

- rewards and penalties calculated every epoch

1101281429156216832.text:
8) roadmap

- ETH 1x in parallel

ETH 2.0 phases:

- phase 0 beacon chain (PoS)

- phase 1 shard chains (sharding)

- Phase 2 shards’ EVM (shard execution, smart contracts, eWASM, storage/state rent) 

- Phase 3 light clients (off chain state storage)
